intro: Galium saccharatum var. pleianthum, commonly known as sweet woodruff, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive whorled arrangement of leaves and small, fragrant flowers. The plant produces white or pale green flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shady environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Its leaves and flowers are used in herbal teas and traditional medicine for their mild sedative and aromatic properties.
